name: Silent Hill Homecoming
description: In Silent Hill Homecoming, Alex Shepherd has returned to his hometown of Shepherd's Glen to investigate the sudden disappearance of his brother. From Shepherd's Glen to the foggy streets of Silent Hill, Alex will face the darkest of horrors while struggling with his own grip on reality.

While it may not be the greatest Silent Hill game it's still a fun game I enjoy it and i find the story interesting While it's fun it has some issues and I found myself crashing a bit overall not worth 40 dollars but i'd say it's worth a buy If you find a sale Btw Konami please bring the classics to steam I will gladly pay for them

I wish I could say Silent Hill: Homecoming is some kind of masterpiece, as it's the only Silent Hill game on Steam, but it is far from it. While not terrible by any means, the game is obviously inferior to its earlier counterparts in numerous ways, and the PC port's various issues - including completely locked 30fps and random crashing, often from alt-tabbing - make for a lackluster experience. The latter can also become particularly infuriating with the game's fairly sporadic save system.

I tried to like it for a few hours but it became obvious... It is a terrible silent hill game. Do yourself a favor, keep the nostalgia of silent hill 2-3 and avoid this game. Or else run the risk of ruining your memories. Why in the world is this the only silent hill game on steam. Who runs Konami...?

Just another buggy piece of junk.   Once I got through the usual black screen startup inherent to a lot of rushed PC games, I had to figure out why the game was running on such a low (often stuttering) framerate on my usually quite decent hardware (core i5 + gtx 770), but after tinkering few minutes with some settings in the config files and trying to overload vsync in nvidia control panel (turning it off gave me terrible screen tearing, which was a pretty bad sign considering my hardware and the game graphics), I got to the conclusion that the game was just performing the best it could and that its coding was just a mess... of course this was confirmed when I encountered ridiculous 5/10 seconds freezes after some cutscenes. The whole thing was starting to make me quite uneasy as save points in this game are set way too far appart, but more on that soon!  Anyway, despite the terrible performance, I still wanted to give it a shot, as I'm a big amateur of the Silent Hill series and actually owned the same game on X360, but never got much far due to the utter annoyance of the combat system in hard difficulty and one awful freeze that made me lost one hour of boring gameplay. But this time I was determined to go through with it, thinking a pretty average game with Akira Yamaoka's music might at least give me a bit of pleasure.  So there i was, wasting another time tediously running around on some cheap scavenger hunt from corridor to corridor in what appears to be an even more cheap knock off of a Silent Hill game, which quickly throws a bunch of cliches from Silent Hill 2 at you without even trying to have its own identity. It's really quite impressive how bad Double Helix was at this, but hardly surprising if you look at their other games or even at the ones from their former companies (nothing really good appart from a bunch of games in the 90's). How they got this gig is mind-boggling and just shows how Konami execs have become out of touch this last decade to the point of trusting these hacks with one of their most emblematic franchise. It's kind of sad from a company that most definitely was at the top of its game from the 8bit to the PS2 era (one of my best gaming memories as a kid where on their SNES games. still remember how seeing their logo screen popping up would instantly reassure me that I was in for some quality gaming time).  But I disgress... Remember what I said about those save points being way too far appart for a buggy game like this? Right after the first level of the game, you get into a really tedious part of the game, which pretty much consists of running around way too much in different parts of the town. I only had one save point in the beginning, but then I got to almost fully explore a house, picked up quite a bunch of stuff, got to explore the first part of a cemetery only to have to backtrack quite far, because I didn't see the right climbing path the first time around. And then, just before I finally got to the next save point, BAM! got accidentely ALT-TABed out of the game, which of course crashed when I tried to get back in it! Almost made me smile... Almost :p. Anyway, I was just looking for a good reason to put this game down early (and forever. this time) and it looks like it made me a favor by collapsing from the weight of its own mediocrity after a mere 1 hour of gameplay.  So there you have it. Think twice before buying this terrible port. Even if you actually remotely enjoyed it on consoles, you're probably going to have a bad time. Besides, there are so much better games like this one to try (hell, even a small indie game like Lone Survivor gets it more). In the meanwhile Konami might pull their head out of their ♥♥♥♥ and redeem themselves by releasing the 4 earliest Silent Hill games on Steam. Hopefully it'll happen before they cut their veins open, while ingesting pachinko balls and frenetically playing DDR until they die while trying to figure out how they can 'revive' another franchise. Yeah... this must how they've been making their decisions lately.

Was a bit spooked when i saw the majority of reviews here, but i mentioned it to a friend and he got it for me. For the first 2 hours i was waiting for something to go wrong, now close to 4 hours I'm confident that a majority of the reviews arent quite the truth. I have a 2014 dell with a family graphics card, the only time this game crashed is when i tried to get back to my checkpoint because i didnt learn the combat yet, which to be honest i deserved to crash. Nothing else since then, there are rare moments when the game stutters but its only temporary. The combat is a bit strange at first but once you get the jist of using shift to enter combat mode its an instant breeze everything else is rudementery, you mainly use the mouse and the space bar aside some inventory but its all clearly laid out. Mouse 0 means M1 and mouse 1 means M2 thats all. The game itself is spectacular i havent felt this kind of fear in a long time, the fear of the unknown you start out knowing almost nothing. That is the beauty of this series, takes me back to times when i played Silent hill 2 on the old Playstation 2. All this to say, not that everyone has the same situation this game is amazing, if you see it on sale its worth the shot. Don't instantly belive all the negativity if your a patient person and love engaging games then give it a go. If it doesnt work its almost more easier to refund than it is to purchaching it, so dont feel afraid. Haha unless your playing! That is all : )

If you intend to play this game, purchase the console version or something. It's an awful port, for example: the audio doesn't work on any chipset that I've ever tried it on. I've installed this game on several machines (mine and my friends') and it doesn't produce sound properly on any of them. I've tried playing it with various integrated, crappy and very common chipsets as well as several Creative Labs and ASUS PCI-E products. None of them work with the game properly; it's astounding. There are other things to pick at, surely, but this is what bothered me the most ...especially since the game heavily relies on sound to create atmosphere and suspense, etcetera. The game itself may or may not sate the desire of a Silent Hill fan's want of a Silent Hill experience. It borrows a few bits from the film and is sort of reminiscent of the visual aesthetics of it's predecessors along with some creative new elements and it's own story-line. Anyhow, if you decide to buy it, good luck!

Despite the mixed opinions about this game, I thought it had a good story and managed to capture the drama of Silent Hill. The graphics are good, and while the soundtrack isn't as remarkable as the previous SH titles, it does fit with most environments of the game. The only issue with this game is how it was poorly ported to PC. It required a lot of patience, with the freezes, glitches and eventual crashes. If you're a hardcore fan of Silent Hill games, you may not mind having to deal with these problems.   But if you never played Silent Hill or are looking for a nice horror game, be advised that this game might not be your best choice to start. Try playing the previous ones first.

After playing fora few hours I think it is a good game. It definately feels like Silent hill, the game has the town, the fog and all the monsters. However I don't feel any attachment to the characters, very little character development so far but I still need to play it more.   If you are considering this game 1) The pc controls are horrendous, you will need a controller 2) Put the game on medium settings because it crashes frequently when on high settings 3) this is a game you would buy on sale.

5th Silent Hill installment. As much as I played before my game actually glitched out and can't go further, the controls are nicely ported over considering this is a console port. Everything feels a bit laggy only because the game has a fps cap of 30 which is hardcoded in. It's a bit confusing at first because the controls aren't explained anywhere but it shouldn't be too hard to figure out. I'd probably stay away from this one since there seems to be a lot of bugs and that 30 fps limit.

Traditional Silent Hill feel mixed with next-generation progression, this title is beautifully detailed, the story is heart-wrenching and perfect, the voice acting is excellent, and the soundtrack is haunting and shakes you to your core. An updated combat system mixed with ending-changing choices makes this one of my most favorite games of all time.
Great game, highly recommended!

I've never wondered could exist a Silent Hill so poorly made and adapted to PC. There are many things on this game that will irritate you all the time. I'll list some of those things below:   -bizarre glitches  -infinite loadings  -annoying freezings -bad support for gamepad controller -low FPS  -bad controller response -annoying camera  -almost invincible bosses with a 'hard-to-find' weak point -a SH that you don't play in SH town (WTF?) -etc -etc -etc  Summarizing: generally, a SH game give you the creeps and some scares, which is something nice when we talk about a survive horror game. But this one will make you more bored and angry than excited the most of the painful gameplay experience. If you intend to buy this game and play it to make you feel 'complete' as a hard fan of SILENT HILL, just like me, think about it twice. Honestly, I cannot say I regret to buy this game, but surely I can tell you SH Homecoming is a really disappointing game for all those reasons I listed above. I hope it could be helpful.
